<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 596, 89]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the density of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 576, 121]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 467, 152]]<|/det|> You are provided with a plastic drinks cup. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[250, 165, 744, 327]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 350, 532, 368]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 381, 146, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 381, 920, 429]]<|/det|> Place the cup, with the base at the bottom, in square \(\mathbf{A}\) on this page. Draw carefully around the base of the cup. Remove the cup from the paper. Take measurements from your drawing to determine an accurate value for the diameter \(D_{\mathrm{B}}\) of the base of the cup. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 444, 635, 755]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 117, 920, 152]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 556, 831, 585]]<|/det|>

[1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 146, 489]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 470, 915, 489]]<|/det|> Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker. Place the thermometer in the beaker of hot water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 501, 175, 520]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 501, 920, 536]]<|/det|> Record in Table 2.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0 \text{s}\). Immediately start the stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 549, 175, 567]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 549, 920, 583]]<|/det|> After \(30 \text{s}\), measure the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Record the time \(t = 30 \text{s}\) and the temperature reading in the table. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 596, 175, 613]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 594, 920, 629]]<|/det|> Continue recording the time and temperature readings every 30 s until you have six sets of readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|> [2] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 655, 539, 674]]<|/det|> Table 2.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 686, 621, 866]]<|/det|>
\(t/\mathrm {s}\)\(\theta /\mathrm {}^{\circ }\mathrm {C}\)

Plot a graph of \(\theta /\mathrm{^\circ C}\) (y-axis) against \(t / \mathrm{s}\) (x-axis). You do **not** need to start the \(y\)-axis at the origin (0,0) but the value of room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) must be marked on the \(y\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 71, 648, 89]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 918, 107]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating whether the distance that a toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 537, 137]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the student:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 152, 218, 167]]<|/det|>
a ramp

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 165, 546, 184]]<|/det|>
blocks to support the ramp as shown in Fig. 4.1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 182, 235, 197]]<|/det|>
toy truck

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 339, 212]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 211, 598, 229]]<|/det|>
other standard apparatus from the physics laboratory.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 243, 920, 276]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate whether the distance that the toy truck will travel along a horizontal floor, before stopping, depends on its mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 289, 537, 307]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this investigation.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 320, 324, 338]]<|/det|>
In your plan, you should:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 655, 369]]<|/det|>
explain briefly how you would carry out the investigation

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 382, 813, 400]]<|/det|>
state any apparatus that you would use that is not included in the list above

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 568, 431]]<|/det|>
state the key variables that you would control

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 444, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
draw a table, or tables, with column headings to show how you would display your readings (you are **not** required to enter any readings in the table).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 641, 508]]<|/det|>
You may add to the diagram in Fig. 4.1 to help your description.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 580, 897, 682]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 766, 532, 785]]<|/det|>
